intro: Ayenia mastersii, commonly known as the Mexican mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees in the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and has a distinctive appearance with small, leathery leaves and white, tubular flowers. The plant produces small, red berries that are a source of food for birds and other wildlife. Its parasitic nature allows it to derive nutrients from its host, while still performing photosynthesis to some extent. Ayenia mastersii is often found in arid and semi-arid environments, where it thrives in the canopy of its host trees.
